prelim.title: Services agreement: short form (with contract details cover sheet; pro-supplier)

para.paratext: A short form agreement for the supply of services, drafted from the supplier's perspective, with key commercial information listed in a table at the front of the agreement. It is intended for use in business-to-business transactions.
This document is a short form agreement for the supply of services in a business-to-business (b2b) context. It is drafted from the supplier's perspective.

In the interests of producing a short form services agreement, we have omitted or shortened various clauses that would usually be included in a longer form services agreement. For more information, see Drafting note, Omitted, shortened and optional clauses.

For information on common legal issues that impact the drafting of services agreements, such as implied terms and limitations of liability, see Standard document, Services agreement (pro-supplier): Drafting note: Legal issues.
In assessing whether it is appropriate to use a short form agreement, relevant considerations include:
The type of transaction. Is it a routine transaction where the risks are known and assessed as not justifying the time and expense of negotiating a long form agreement?

The nature and value of the services. Are the services of a low value? Are the services straight-forward to deliver and not particularly bespoke to the customer? How crucial are the services to each party's business?

Each party's risk profile. What level of risk is each party willing to accept? The more risks that a party faces, the more it is likely to want to use a longer form agreement with wider contractual protections.
The budget for negotiations. Is there a limited budget for legal and professional fees?
The transaction timetable. Is there enough time to negotiate a long form agreement?

head.headtext: Drawbacks of using a short form agreement

para.paratext: A short form supply of services agreement will, by its nature, not incorporate as full a range of supplier-protection provisions as a longer form agreement. Users of this document should therefore consider carefully whether a short form agreement is appropriate in the context of the particular transaction they are working on.

Even if confident that a short form agreement is suitable for a particular transaction, we advise that you have regard to a long form supply of services agreement when drafting (for links, see Drafting note, Alternative agreements). If there are aspects of the transaction that are of particular importance or concern to the supplier and are not fully addressed in this short form document, relevant provisions from the long form agreement could be included.
In the interests of keeping the document as short as possible, certain clauses from our longer form services agreements have been omitted, shortened or made optional.
These include clauses that deal with the following:

Transfer of employees. Under the Transfer of Undertakings (Protection of Employment) Regulations 2006 (SI 2006/246) (TUPE), if there is a "service provision change" (essentially a change in the entity responsible for providing services), any employees assigned to an organised group whose main purpose is performing those services will automatically transfer to the new service provider on their current employment terms. A service provision change can happen where a customer engages a supplier to provide services for the first time, or changes its supplier of services, or terminates a service contract and starts to perform services in-house. For full information on when TUPE will apply on a service provision change, see Practice note, TUPE (3): service provision changes. If there is a risk that individuals may transfer to the supplier via TUPE when the services begin, the supplier should consider obtaining appropriate warranties and indemnities from the customer, for which see Standard document, Services agreement (pro-supplier): Schedule 6. A short form services agreement is often used where the services are relatively low value. In that scenario, there may not be an organised group whose main purpose is providing the services. For that reason, TUPE may not apply and we have not included TUPE clauses as standard in this agreement.

Specific compliance requirements. This short form agreement does not include individual clauses to address compliance-related issues such as anti-bribery, modern slavery and prevention of tax evasion and fraud. Instead, there is a generic obligation on the supplier at clause 3.2(c)(i) to comply with applicable laws and business policies. The supplier should consider whether these commitments will be sufficient for its customers. For more detailed drafting for compliance risks, see Toolkit, Supply chain compliance toolkit: Compliance clauses: general or specific.

Varying the service description. There is no formal change control mechanism for proposing and agreeing changes to the services. For a supplier-friendly change control procedure, see Standard document, Services agreement (pro-supplier): clause 9.

Servicing affiliates. The supplier only services the customer under this agreement. There is no drafting to enable the supplier to service customer affiliates on the terms of this agreement. For this drafting, see Standard document, Services agreement (pro-supplier): clause 6.

Exclusive purchasing. There is no clause requiring the customer to buy specific services exclusively from the supplier. For this drafting, see Standard clause, Exclusive purchasing and supply clause: short form.

Non-solicitation. Longer form, supplier-friendly services agreements often contain drafting preventing the customer from poaching the supplier's staff (see Standard document, Services agreement (pro-supplier): clause 7). This drafting is not included in this short form agreement.

Governance. This short form agreement does not include any drafting for review meetings, reports or the use of contract managers to manage the relationship. For governance drafting, see Standard clause, Governance.

Dispute resolution. While this agreement contains a governing law and jurisdiction clause, there is no dispute resolution procedure (for example, requiring disputes to be referred to mediation). For dispute resolution drafting, see Standard document, Services agreement (pro-supplier): clause 30.

As this agreement is drafted from the supplier's perspective, the above list does not include additional provisions that might benefit the customer. For a pro-customer agreement, see Standard document, Services agreement: short form (with contract details cover sheet; pro-customer).

The following clauses are significantly shorter than those in longer form services agreements. The drafting notes to the clauses link to more extensive drafting and a discussion of the relevant provisions.
Interpretation (clause 1).
Intellectual property rights (clause 6).
Termination (clause 9).
General (clause 10).
For a fuller agreement covering the supply of services, see the following standard documents:
Services agreement (pro-supplier).
Simple framework services agreement (pro-supplier).
This agreement is drafted on the following assumptions:

Services agreed upfront. This agreement is for the provision of an agreed set of services. It does not provide for the procurement and provision of other services through statements of work (SOWs) under its terms. If this is required, see Standard document, Simple framework services agreement (pro-supplier).
Primarily services. The agreement is primarily for the provision of services, although some materials may be provided as part of or result from the services.

B2B. The parties are dealing with each other in the course of their respective businesses, meaning that the UK rules protecting consumers will not apply. This agreement is therefore not suitable for use in business-to-consumer transactions. For resources on consumer law, including business-to-consumer terms and conditions, see Consumer law toolkit.
Terms not industry specific. This agreement does not account for any industry-specific laws or rules that may apply to certain transactions.

UK companies. The customer and supplier are companies incorporated in England and Wales. This agreement is not for use by public bodies procuring services. The procurement of services by public bodies is subject to specific procurement rules. For a services agreement that can be used by a public sector body, see Standard document, Services agreement for use by public sector bodies.
English law. The agreement is subject to English law.
The document is made up of the following parts:

Contract Details. At the front of the document is a cover sheet entitled "Contract Details" which, when completed, will contain the key variable terms. Putting these terms here should make it easier to prepare the document. It also provides a quick overview of key terms and may perhaps give the impression (to the supplier's benefit) that the other terms are not to be changed.
Conditions. The main terms of the agreement are in the Conditions attached to the cover sheet. The cover sheet has a section for recording any agreed amendments to the Conditions.
Schedules. The agreement allows for the incorporation of optional schedules, including:

Schedule 1. A full specification for the services can be set out in a schedule where there is insufficient space to describe the services in the cover sheet. For the importance of a comprehensive services description, see Drafting note, Services (optional schedule).
Schedule 2. The charges and invoicing arrangements could be set out in a schedule, if they will not fit on the cover sheet.

Schedule 3. The supplier can list business policies that it will adhere to, for example, in relation to ethical business conduct and anti-bribery measures. In a pro-supplier agreement, the supplier may choose to omit compliance with policies from a first draft. If the supplier does include a commitment to comply with policies (for example, because customers frequently expect this), it may prefer to list its own business conduct policies. This should make compliance easier and remove the need for the supplier to review customer policies and check for differences with its own.
Schedule 4. If the supplier is processing personal data on behalf of the customer, it can include the terms necessary to satisfy the UK GDPR in this schedule.

The Contract Details, Conditions, and Schedules are incorporated into the agreement by the wording in paragraph 1 at the bottom of the table on the cover sheet. The priority of the various parts making up the agreement is set out in paragraph 2, followed by the signature block.
Ensure that there is a page break between the Contract Details and the Conditions.
The contract should be dated the day the last party signs it.

The services and deliverables should be described in the Contract Details table. Further detail can be added in Schedule 1 if necessary. Delete the references to Schedule 1, and the schedule itself, if it is not used.

The charges for the services should be specified either in the Contract Details table or in Schedule 2. Alternatively, the supplier could refer to a price list current at the date of the agreement. Delete the reference to Schedule 2, and the schedule itself, if it is not used.

This document envisages that the Conditions will remain unchanged. Any amendments can be set out opposite the words "Special terms" in the Contract Details table, using the optional text as appropriate for when a clause is deleted, added or amended.
If the changes are lengthy they could be set out in an additional schedule. If there are no special terms then delete this row of the table and the reference to "Special terms".
Remove any schedules that are not used from the Contract Details table.

Underneath the Contract Details table, paragraph 1 explains the different parts of the contract and paragraph 2 sets out the order of precedence in the event of conflicts between them. Check that the order proposed is correct for your contract. In any event, the different parts should be closely scrutinised and amended to resolve any conflicts which can be identified in advance.

A court will, insofar as possible, read the different parts as complementing each other and only resort to the order of precedence in the case of a clear and irreconcilable discrepancy. For more information on conflicts clauses, see Standard clause, Conflict.

This clause 3 sets out the principal obligations of the supplier with regard to the services. While it would be possible to include fewer obligations, the key areas of concern for customers have been included in the interests of reaching an agreement.

Services contracts are governed by the Supply of Goods and Services Act 1982 (SGSA) and the common law. For information on terms implied into services contracts by the SGSA and common law, see Practice note, Drafting standard terms and conditions for the supply of services.
The Supplier shall supply the Services to the Customer from the Effective Date in accordance with the Contract [in all material respects].
In supplying the Services, the Supplier shall:
perform the Services with reasonable care and skill [in accordance with the generally recognised standards and practices in its industry];

head.headtext: Care and skill in the provision of the services

para.paratext: The SGSA implies a term that the supplier will carry out services with reasonable care and skill (section 13). The supplier could therefore omit this clause.

However, many suppliers opt to include a clause on the standard of services because customers expect to see it and to pre-empt customers inserting wording that imposes a higher standard, for example by reference to "best industry practice".
Use the optional wording in brackets where the supplier wants to make clear that its performance will be in line with standard practice in its industry.

This agreement does not commit the supplier to meeting service levels or include a scheme whereby the customer receives credits against the cost of the services if service levels are not achieved. Instead, if the supplier fails to achieve the required standard for the services, the customer will have to claim damages and possibly terminate (see clause 8 for limitations on the supplier's liability and clause 9 for the customer's contractual termination rights).
Drafting for a service level and service credit regime can be found in Standard document, Outsourcing agreement: shorter form: clause 7.

Although service credits may seem to be pro-customer provisions, provided they are well drafted they can benefit a supplier if they are the customer's exclusive remedy for a certain degree of under-performance.

use [all] reasonable endeavours to meet any performance dates specified in the Contract but these dates are estimates only. Time is not of the essence for the performance of any of the Supplier's obligations in the Contract;
This clause 3.2(b) seeks to limit the customer's remedies if performance dates are not met. It provides that:

Time is not of the essence in respect of performance dates. If time were of the essence for a deadline, the customer would have a right to terminate if the deadline was missed. If there is no statement that time is of the essence, a party might argue that this term should be implied. Including the statement that time is not of the essence in clause 3.2(b) should defeat that argument. For more information on time of the essence obligations, see Practice note, Time of the essence.
The supplier need only use reasonable (or all reasonable) endeavours to meet performance dates, which in any case are just estimates.
Where the time for performance is not fixed in the contract or by the parties' course of dealing, section 14 of the SGSA requires the supplier to carry out the services within a reasonable time.

Clause 3.2(c) is a general compliance clause requiring the supplier to comply with all applicable laws and, optionally, certain business policies which can be listed in optional Schedule 3. For more information, see Drafting note, Policies (optional definition).
This clause obliges the supplier to bear the costs of complying with the law and policies.

The supplier may want to suggest that some costs caused by changes to the law should be borne by the customer. For drafting requiring the customer to agree to changes to the services and charges where necessary to comply with changes in law, see Standard document, Services agreement (pro-supplier): clause 9.6.

[use reasonable endeavours to] ensure its staff observe all reasonable health and safety and security requirements that apply at any of the Customer's premises they access and have been communicated to the Supplier in advance in writing. The Supplier shall not be liable under the Contract if, as a result of observing these requirements, it is in breach of any of its other obligations under the Contract.

head.headtext: Compliance with health and safety and security requirements (optional clause)

para.paratext: This optional clause 3.2(d) is unlikely to be necessary if supplier personnel will have negligible access to customer premises. In any event, the supplier may not want to offer any obligations to comply with health and safety or security requirements at customer premises in a first draft.

This clause 4 sets out some general obligations on the customer. However, if the customer has significant responsibilities, or there are specific obligations which the customer must carry out before the supplier can perform the contracted services ("customer dependencies"), it may be best to set them out in a schedule to avoid future disputes and to ensure it is clear that the supplier's ability to deliver is dependent on the customer first meeting those dependencies. For an example, see Standard document, Outsourcing agreement: shorter form: Schedule 7, Customer's Responsibilities.
The Customer shall:
co-operate with the Supplier in all matters relating to the Services [and ensure that its other suppliers co-operate with the Supplier where reasonably necessary];

provide the Supplier and its subcontractors, in a timely manner, with access to the Customer's premises and other facilities as [reasonably] required by the Supplier for the performance of the Services;

provide the Supplier, in a timely manner, with all information and materials as the Supplier may [reasonably] require to provide the Services and ensure that they are accurate and complete [in all material respects]; [and]
comply with all Applicable Laws in its performance of the Contract[; and OR .]
[ANY OTHER OBLIGATIONS.]

For other customer obligations to consider including, see Standard document, Services agreement (pro-supplier): clause 5.1. For example, the supplier may want to include drafting requiring the customer to provide prompt feedback on draft deliverables submitted for approval.

To the extent that the Supplier's performance of its obligations under the Contract is prevented or delayed by any act or omission of the Customer or any of its agents, consultants or other suppliers (Excusing Cause), the Supplier shall not be in breach of the Contract nor liable for any Losses incurred by the Customer as a result of its performance being prevented or delayed. Without prejudice to any other right or remedy it may have, the Supplier shall be:
allowed an extension of time to perform its obligations equal to the delay caused by the Excusing Cause;
entitled to payment of the Charges despite its performance being prevented or delayed; and
entitled to recover any Losses, including additional costs, incurred as a result of the Excusing Cause.

This clause 4.2 seeks to ensure that if the customer's action (or inaction) results in delay or non-performance by the supplier, the supplier incurs no liability, still gets paid and can recover any additional costs it incurs.

While it may be possible to claim this relief under the common law without this drafting, some suppliers prefer to include specific provisions in their services agreements for certainty. Suppliers should be wary of customers introducing drafting that restricts the remedies that the supplier would otherwise have at common law, for example by:
Restricting the compensation which the supplier may claim.
Making the supplier's right to claim subject to the supplier giving the customer notice of the delay and taking specified steps to mitigate its effects.
Omitting the "without prejudice to any other right or remedy" wording.
Each party shall comply with its data protection obligations set out in Schedule 4.
This is an optional clause for inclusion if the supplier will be processing personal data pursuant to the UK GDPR in connection with the performance of the services.

The UK GDPR defines processing widely to include, among other things, collection, recording, storage and exchange of personal data. For a start, the parties should consider the context and purpose in which personal data is being processed. For example:

The personal data is processed as part of the service offering. An example would be where the supplier is engaged to provide an online survey to the customer's employees or end-users. Here, the supplier would be processing the personal data (of the employees or end-users) on the customer's behalf as its processor.

The personal data is processed for general contract management or communication purposes as opposed to being part of the service offering. For example, the agreement is for the provision of office cleaning services which, in itself, does not require the processing of any personal data. However, each party may provide the names and email addresses of employees who are responsible for managing the contract and dealing with the other party for that purpose. Each party processes this data as independent controllers.

For a list of issues to consider when determining the parties' relationship, see Checklist, Controller or processor? (UK and EU). Having ascertained the type of relationship, the parties can then insert the appropriate data protection provisions to reflect that relationship:
Controller-processor relationship. In a controller-processor relationship, the UK GDPR requires certain contractual terms to be documented in a binding written processing agreement.

Controller-controller relationship. Unlike in a controller-processor relationship, there is no obligation on businesses to document their relationship or their respective responsibilities where each is acting as an independent controller in respect of the same personal data. However, businesses sharing personal data sometimes want to include drafting to protect themselves from legal risks and demonstrate that they are taking their responsibilities as a controller seriously.
In Schedule 4, there are:

Controller-processor clauses required by the UK GDPR. As this is a supplier-friendly agreement, the drafting does not go beyond the minimum necessary to comply with the UK GDPR and gives the supplier as much flexibility as possible in the way in which it processes customer data. For example, the customer gives prior general authorisation for the supplier to appoint sub-processors and transfer personal data outside the UK.

Basic compliance with law commitments that would apply to data sharing as independent controllers. Again, as this is a pro-supplier agreement, the commitments are light. If the only processing of personal data is as independent controllers, the supplier could choose to omit the schedule altogether.
The drafting in Schedule 4 is partly based on the following standard clauses which provide background information and further drafting if necessary:
Data processing clauses (UK).

Personal data processing clauses for IT agreements (UK) (pro-supplier) (while this is drafted with an IT focus, the general principles and drafting approach are just as applicable to a non-IT-based agreement).
Personal data sharing clauses (controller to controller, short-form) (UK).

head.headtext: When IPRs are relevant in services agreements

para.paratext: IPRs are relevant in contracts for services wherever:

The customer is providing the supplier with something in which IPRs subsist to enable the supplier to perform the services (for example, its branding or information about its products). In this agreement, these things are defined as "Customer Materials".

The supplier is, as part of the services, providing the customer with something in which IPRs subsist. These might include materials (such as instructions or software) which the supplier or a third party has already developed or materials developed as part of the services (such as bespoke reports or advertising creative). The supplier may:

licence the customer to use materials where the supplier wants to continue using the materials itself. This is usually the case with materials developed before the services start and is sometimes the case with materials developed as part of the services; or

assign ownership of materials to the customer. This is often what the customer wants in relation to materials developed as part of the services. But if the supplier's business model is that materials developed under one client contract can be used in its services generally, including with other clients, it will only want to license these materials on a non-exclusive basis.
This agreement takes the following approach:
The customer licenses the supplier to use customer materials to provide the services.
The supplier retains ownership of all intellectual property rights in the deliverables (excluding any customer materials, ownership of which is retained by the customer).
The supplier grants the customer a non-exclusive licence to use the deliverables. Options for the duration of the licence and whether sub-licensing is permitted are included in square brackets.

If the supplier wants to include third party-owned materials in the deliverables and those materials cannot be licensed on the same terms as the deliverables (for example, because they are only licensed on the third party's standard terms), the supplier will either obtain the customer's consent to include them or, in a more supplier-friendly version, simply inform the customer of the licensing terms.

If the supplier will be assigning ownership of the deliverables, rather than licensing them, see Standard document, Services agreement (pro-customer): clause 10 for suggested wording. As well as an assignment, this drafting includes:

A carve-out from the assignment for any of the supplier's proprietary materials included in the deliverables. The supplier continues to own these materials and licenses the customer to use them instead of assigning them.
A licence from the customer to the supplier to use the deliverables that are assigned to the customer. The supplier needs to continue to use those materials to service the customer.
The Supplier and its licensors shall retain ownership of all Intellectual Property Rights in the Deliverables, excluding any Customer Materials contained within them.

[Subject [to clause 6.4 and] to the Supplier receiving payment of all Charges attributable to the Deliverables,] the Supplier grants to the Customer a non-exclusive, royalty-free, non-transferable (except in accordance with clause 10.2), [perpetual [and irrevocable] licence OR licence during the term of the Contract] [(with the right to grant sublicences)] to use, copy and modify the Deliverables for the purpose of receiving and using the Services and Deliverables in the Customer's business.

If the customer accepts a licence (rather than an assignment) of the deliverables, it will want the licence to be perpetual and ideally irrevocable. If there are any elements of the deliverables that the supplier cannot license perpetually (for example, because they are proprietary tools that can only be used by existing customers), those items could be carved out from a perpetual licence to the customer and, instead, licensed for the term of the agreement (or a different period).

Clause 6.2 includes optional, supplier-friendly wording so that the licence is subject to the customer paying for the deliverables. Some customers may object to this and argue that the supplier has remedies if the customer fails to pay or is late making payments. From the supplier's perspective, making the customer's usage of the deliverables contingent on payment is useful leverage to ensure payments are made on time.

Include the optional wording about having the right to grant sublicences if the customer is free to sublicense use of the deliverables. Alternatively, delete this optional wording and use optional clause 6.3 which includes a complete or partial restriction on sublicensing without consent.
The Customer [shall not sublicense the rights granted in clause 6.2 without the Supplier's prior written consent OR may sublicense the rights granted in clause 6.2:
to its Affiliates [and customers]; and
other third parties with the Supplier's prior written consent].

[The Customer acknowledges that the Supplier may need to include materials belonging to third parties which cannot be licensed on the terms of clause 6.2 (Third Party Materials) within the Deliverables OR The Supplier shall not include in the Deliverables any materials belonging to third parties that cannot be licensed to the Customer on the terms of clause 6.2 (Third Party Materials) unless their inclusion and licence terms are approved in writing in advance by the Customer]. The Supplier shall grant to the Customer a licence (at the Customer's cost) to use any Third Party Materials [included in OR approved by the Customer for inclusion in] the Deliverables on the terms [permitted by the third party OR approved by the Customer]. The Customer shall comply with the terms (including any usage restrictions) that apply to the Third Party Materials and which have been [provided to the Customer OR approved by the Customer] in writing. [The Supplier's liability in relation to Third Party Materials shall be limited to the liability accepted by the third party under the relevant licence agreement.]
This clause 6.4 includes two options for the licensing of third party materials that cannot be licensed on the same terms as clause 6.2:

Option 1. The supplier is able to include third party materials in the deliverables without the customer's prior approval of the materials or their licence terms. The customer must comply with any usage restrictions made known to the customer in writing. Use the first set of wording in each square bracket if using this option. This is the most supplier-friendly option.

Option 2. The supplier is only able to include third party materials in the deliverables with the customer's prior approval of the materials and their licence terms. The customer must comply with any usage restrictions approved by the customer in writing. Use the second set of wording in each square bracket if using this option.
The final sentence is optional wording to limit the supplier's liability for third party materials to the liability that the third party accepts.

The Customer and its licensors shall retain ownership of all Intellectual Property Rights in the Customer Materials. The Customer grants the Supplier a non-exclusive, royalty-free licence to use, copy and modify the Customer Materials during the term of the Contract for the purpose of providing the Services to the Customer. The Supplier may grant sublicences of the Customer Materials to its subcontractors and other suppliers where necessary for the performance of the Services.

The Supplier shall indemnify the Customer against all [Losses incurred by the Customer OR sums awarded against the Customer by a court] as a result of any claim that the supply, receipt or use of any of the Deliverables infringes the Intellectual Property Rights of any third party. The Supplier shall not be liable under this indemnity to the extent that the actual or alleged infringement arises from:
any changes made to the Deliverables without the Supplier's prior written consent (not to be unreasonably withheld);
instructions, information or materials provided by the Customer for the development of the Deliverables; or

the use of the Deliverables for a purpose or in a manner not authorised by the Supplier or the failure of the Customer to adhere to the Supplier's [reasonable] instructions for the use of the Deliverables.

The Customer shall indemnify the Supplier against all [Losses incurred by the Supplier OR sums awarded against the Supplier by a court] as a result of any claim that the supply, receipt or use of the Customer Materials infringes the Intellectual Property Rights of any third party. The Customer shall not be liable under this indemnity to the extent that the actual or alleged infringement arises from the use of the Customer Materials for a purpose or in a manner not authorised by the Customer.

There is a risk that both the deliverables and the customer materials may infringe third party intellectual property rights. If the risk that the deliverables infringe third party rights is greater, it may be preferable to omit any indemnities altogether. However, if the risk of the customer materials infringing third party rights is high or if the customer insists on an indemnity in respect of the deliverables infringing third party rights, then the supplier may need to include an appropriate clause.

Use the second set of optional wording in each indemnity to limit recovery to sums awarded by a court and not other costs (for example, costs in relation to settled claims). It is more typical for an indemnity to be comprehensive, covering "all losses". Many customers expect full indemnity protection from suppliers creating materials for them. Use the first option in each indemnity for that drafting.

Unless the indemnity from the supplier at clause 6.6 is stated to be outside the general cap on the supplier's liability in clause 8, it will be within it. There is optional wording in clause 8 to exclude indemnities from the limitations on liability or to include a separate liability cap for them.
If the customer's liability is uncapped in this agreement, the customer's IPR indemnity would also be uncapped.

The supplier may want to include drafting giving it the right to avoid any third party infringement claim by procuring a licence to use the infringing deliverables or modifying them so that they cease to infringe. For this drafting, see Standard document, Services agreement (pro-supplier): clause 11.7.

The supplier may also want to consider including conduct of claims wording, for example, requiring the customer to let the supplier control the defence of any third party claim that the deliverables infringe IPRs. For more information and drafting, see Standard clause, Indemnity.
There are a number of different mechanisms for pricing arrangements. These can be on a time and materials basis, a fixed fee basis or a combination of the two.

A time and materials fee approach can benefit the supplier because it allows the supplier to charge for all the work it actually does. With a fixed price for services and a demanding customer, the supplier may risk providing more services than the customer has actually paid for.
For more information on charging methods, see Standard document, Services agreement (pro-supplier): Drafting note: Charges and payment.

This short form agreement does not include a clause allowing the supplier to increase the charges during the contract term. This type of drafting is unlikely to be necessary if the services are provided only for a short period of time. If this drafting is required, see Standard document, Services agreement (pro-supplier): clause 10.4.
In consideration for the provision of the Services, the Customer shall pay the Supplier the Charges in accordance with this clause 7.
The Customer shall reimburse the Supplier for the following expenses and costs which are excluded from the Charges:

the cost of hotel, subsistence, travelling and any other ancillary expenses reasonably incurred by the Supplier's personnel in connection with the Services (Expenses)[, provided that the Supplier obtains the Customer's prior written approval before incurring [any individual expense item exceeding [AMOUNT] OR any expenses over [AMOUNT] in any calendar month]]; and

the cost to the Supplier of any materials or services procured by the Supplier from third parties for the provision of the Services (Third Party Costs)[, provided that the Supplier obtains the Customer's prior written approval before incurring [any individual Third Party Cost exceeding [AMOUNT] OR any Third Party Costs over [AMOUNT] in any calendar month]].
Clause 7.2 provides for certain expenses and third party costs to be payable in addition to the charges.
There is optional wording requiring the supplier to obtain the customer's approval for any individual expense or cost or aggregated expenses or costs over a certain amount.

All sums payable by the Customer exclude amounts in respect of value added tax (VAT). The Customer shall, on receipt of a valid VAT invoice from the Supplier, pay to the Supplier any additional amounts in respect of VAT as are chargeable on those sums.

Unless the contract provides otherwise, the price of the services will be deemed to be inclusive of VAT (section 19(2), Value Added Tax Act 1994). In b2b contracts, prices typically exclude VAT because businesses can generally recover all or part of the amounts paid in respect of VAT as input tax.

The Supplier shall invoice the Customer for the Charges [at the [start OR end] of each month for Services [performed in that month OR to be performed in the following month] OR at the intervals specified in Schedule 2].
Clause 7.4 includes drafting for different invoicing options, including:

Monthly in advance. Invoices issued at the start of the month for the next month's activity. This way, the supplier is paid before it starts providing the next month's services. If the supplier's charges are variable (for example, where it charges on a time and materials basis), invoicing in advance is unlikely to work. If the customer objects to invoicing in the month before activity, the supplier could suggest invoicing at the start of the month in which the work takes place, meaning it will be paid at the end of that month (assuming 30-day payment terms).

Monthly in arrears. Invoices are issued at the end of the month in which activity takes place. The downside of this approach for the supplier is that it has to wait to be paid for a month after work is completed.

The Supplier shall invoice the Customer monthly in arrears for Expenses and Third Party Costs. [The Supplier shall provide invoices or receipts for Expenses and Third Party Costs if requested by the Customer.]

head.headtext: Invoicing schedule for expenses and third party costs

para.paratext: The default position is that the supplier invoices the customer in arrears for expenses and third party costs. This approach is usually acceptable for a supplier where the volume of expenses and third party costs is relatively low.

If the supplier will be incurring significant third party costs for the customer's benefit but does not want to pay for those costs out of its own funds, it could include a clause allowing it to invoice earlier so that it receives funds from the customer before it has to pay the third party. For drafting, see Standard document, Services agreement (pro-supplier): clause 10.8.
The Customer shall pay each invoice submitted to it by the Supplier within [30] days of [the invoice date OR receipt] to a bank account nominated in writing by the Supplier.
Without prejudice to any other right or remedy that the Supplier may have, if the Customer fails to pay any sum due to the Supplier under the Contract by the due date:

the Customer shall pay interest on the overdue sum from the due date until payment of the overdue sum, whether before or after judgment. Interest under this clause will accrue each day at [4]% a year above the [Bank of England's] base rate from time to time, but at [4]% a year for any period when that base rate is below 0%; and
For information on interest clauses, see the drafting notes to Standard clause, Interest.
the Supplier may suspend all or part of the Services until payment has been made in full.

All amounts due under the Contract from the Customer to the Supplier shall be paid in full without any set-off, counterclaim, deduction or withholding (other than any deduction or withholding of tax as required by law).

The parties will each have set-off rights under common law. This clause excludes the customer's right of set-off. If the Conditions constitute written standard terms, this may give rise to UCTA issues. For information on set-off clauses, see the drafting notes to Standard clause, Set-off. For optional wording requiring the customer to gross up any payments subject to withholding tax so that the supplier receives the full amount, see Standard document, Services agreement (pro-supplier): clause 10.10(b).
Limitation of liability is always a key issue in a services contract and is likely to be heavily negotiated between the parties. Tailor this clause 8 for your particular transaction.
This clause sets out a typical structure for a limitation of liability clause which is commonly found in services agreements. It is divided into the following sections:

Unlimited liabilities. Neither party limits those liabilities which cannot be limited as a matter of law. There is also the option to leave other potential liabilities unlimited, such as those arising from failure to pay amounts due.

Treatment of certain categories of loss. The clause provides wording to exclude certain categories of loss, such as indirect and consequential loss. In some agreements, the clause may then make exceptions to this exclusion, so that certain types of loss or specific losses are recoverable. For example, the agreement could specify that wasted expenditure in general is excluded but that certain specific costs are not. Or that loss of business in general is excluded but loss of a particular client or contract is not. As this is a pro-supplier agreement, there is no clause specifying losses that are not excluded (and therefore definitely recoverable) as this is usually for the customer's benefit. For this drafting, see Standard clause, Limitation of liability: clause 1.7.
Capped liabilities. Each party limits all other liabilities which might arise to a capped amount.
For more information on limitations of liability and alternative drafting, see Standard clause, Limitation of liability.
The following definitions apply in this clause 8:
contract year: each 12-month period starting on the Effective Date or an anniversary of it;
Delete clause 8.1(a) if there is no annual liability cap (see Drafting note, Liability cap).
default: any act or omission resulting in one party incurring liability to the other; and
liability: every kind of liability arising under or in connection with the Contract including liability in contract, tort (including negligence) or otherwise.

Clause 8.1(c) is designed to ensure that the caps and exclusions capture not just liability for breach of contract but also other liabilities "in connection with" the contract. These could include liability for breach of confidence, misrepresentation, undue influence, or torts such as negligence, conversion and breach of statutory duty. For more information about this clause, see Standard clause, Limitation of liability: Drafting note: Scope of this clause (long form).
Nothing in the Contract limits or excludes:
liability for deliberate default;
liability for death or personal injury caused by negligence to the extent preserved by section 2(1) of the Unfair Contract Terms Act 1977;
liability for fraud or fraudulent misrepresentation;
liability for breach of the terms implied by section 2 of the Supply of Goods and Services Act 1982;
any liability that cannot legally be limited; [or]
[the Customer's OR either party's] liability for its payment obligations under the Contract; [or]
either party's liability under the indemnities in clause 6.
Clause 8.2 sets out exceptions to the limitations of liability.

Where a party's liability is limited, there is a risk that it will decide that it is cheaper to walk away from a contract, or simply not perform part of it, and incur the limited liability rather than the costs of complying with the contract. Optional clause 8.2(a) is intended to deter a party from doing this by disapplying the limits and exclusions where liability arises from deliberate default.

Alternatively, if the supplier would like to make certain that liability for deliberate default falls within the limits and exclusions of liability, it should delete clause 8.2(a) and add "deliberate default" to the definition of liability in clause 8.1(c).

head.headtext: Liabilities which parties cannot legally limit

para.paratext: Statute prohibits the limitation or exclusion of the claims listed in clause 8.2(b) and clause 8.2(d).

Case law establishes that, as a matter of public policy, a party cannot exclude liability for its own fraudulent misrepresentation inducing contract formation. It is not entirely clear whether a party can exclude its liability for other types of fraud (particularly by a party's agents). However, in practice, parties generally want losses resulting from fraud to be uncapped and clause 8.2(c) aims to achieve this.

The intention of a limitation clause is to cap liability for breach of the parties' non-financial obligations such as breach of confidentiality or wrongful termination of the agreement. A supplier will not want to cap the customer's duties to make agreed payments such as the price and interest on late payments.

Clause 8.2(f) therefore removes the cap from the customer's payment obligations arising under the agreement. The drafting also has the effect that the customer's payment obligations cannot fall within any of the categories of excluded loss in clause 8.4. The supplier may choose to make the clause mutual, presenting it as balanced although the bulk of the payment obligations are likely to rest with the customer.

Under clause 8.2(g), the IPR indemnities in clause 6 can optionally be excluded from the limitations of liability. This is often the case in services agreement, although the supplier may instead want to propose that the IPR indemnities are capped, either under the general cap or at a higher level than the general liability cap (see clause 8.3(a)). If the supplier is more likely to be the indemnifying party under the IPR indemnities, it is in its interests to cap liability under them.

In a particularly pro-supplier agreement, the supplier could propose that the customer's liabilities under its IPR indemnity are unlimited, while the supplier's liabilities under the IPR indemnity it gives are limited. However, it is likely to be more acceptable to customers and smoother to negotiate if the approach is mutual.
Subject to clause 8.2, [the Supplier's OR each party's] total liability:
under the indemnity it gives in clause 6 shall not exceed [AMOUNT];
[for breaches occurring in any contract year] under Schedule 4 shall not exceed [AMOUNT]; and

for all [other] loss or damage [arising from defaults occurring within any contract year] shall not exceed [[AMOUNT] OR the greater of [AMOUNT] and [100]% of the Charges paid [or payable] to the Supplier under the Contract] [in that contract year].
There are various ways to structure a liability cap (see Practice note, Limiting liability: drafting and negotiating: Ways to structure a cap).
This clause 8.3 allows the supplier or each party to have separate liability caps for:

Intellectual property infringement. There is optional wording to cap liability for breach of the IPR indemnities in clause 6 at an amount that is separate to, and likely greater than, the general liability cap. This is a compromise between unlimited liability and liability being limited under the general cap. If using this option, delete the optional wording in clause 8.2(g).

Losses arising from breaches of data protection obligations. If the supplier will be processing personal data on the customer's behalf, then the parties may want to include a separate cap for losses arising from data processing breaches. Given the potentially high fines under the UK GDPR, the supplier is likely to want a financial cap on its liability to the customer for data processing breaches. A customer that agrees to this is likely to want this cap to be separate from, and in addition to, the contract's overall liability cap. This avoids the risk that a data processing liability claim might exhaust all or most of a general cap, so that there is none left for other liabilities that are subsequently incurred. A separate cap for data protection breaches has become fairly common in services agreement. The supplier may need to offer it to prevent the customer insisting on unlimited liability instead.
Other losses. This general cap is drafted as either:

a fixed amount. This may be most appropriate where the value of the contract is clear from the start. The fixed amount could simply be a multiple of the total sums payable over the full term of the agreement; or

the greater of a fixed amount and a percentage of charges. This may be most appropriate where the parties are uncertain of what the charges will be and also want to ensure that a minimum amount is recoverable in the early days of the contract, where few services have been supplied and so the charges are low.
The data protection and general caps provide two options:
A single cap for the duration of the contract. This option is likely to be best where the contract is short term.

An annual cap. This option is often used where services are provided over several years. For the customer, an annual cap avoids a situation in which the supplier, having paid out compensation once, has little or no liability for the remainder of the contract term. For the supplier, an annual cap prevents a situation in which the supplier's liability, if linked to the charges, increases year on year in a long term contract.
Use the "contract year" wording for an annual cap and remove it for a single cap.
This clause 8.3 can provide a mutual cap on each party's liability. Alternatively, it can just cap the supplier's liability leaving the customer's liability as uncapped.
For other drafting options, including separate liability caps for the customer and supplier, see Standard clause, Limitation of liability.
Subject to clause 8.2, neither party shall have any liability for:
loss of profits (including loss of anticipated savings);
loss of business or business opportunity;
loss of use or corruption of software, data or information;
loss of or damage to goodwill; or
indirect or consequential loss.
This clause 8.4 sets out the types of losses that a supplier may want to exclude.

Before deciding which losses to exclude, the supplier should identify the risks it faces and the legal constraints on excluding liability. If the supplier's drafting leaves the customer without a meaningful remedy for breach, the clause risks being ineffective (see Practice note, Limiting liability: interpretation: Interpreting a total exclusion).

Each party should also bear in mind that a more moderate position is easier to negotiate. A supplier will expect to see some exclusions from liability, while a customer will not expect to see a long list of excluded losses.
For more information about drafting and negotiating this clause, see Standard clause, Limitation of liability: Drafting note: Losses that are excluded.

For supplier-friendly drafting that relieves the supplier of liability where the customer uses draft deliverables as finished work without the supplier's consent, see Standard document, Services agreement (pro-supplier): clause 5.2.

Subject to clause 8.2, all conditions, warranties, representations or other terms that might otherwise be implied into this agreement by statute, common law or otherwise are excluded from the Contract.
Sections 3 to 5 of the SGSA (in respect of goods transferred under a services contract) imply terms that goods:
Will match their description (section 3, SGSA).
Are of satisfactory quality and fit for their purpose (section 4, SGSA).
Conform to any sample and be free from defects (section 5, SGSA).
Section 13 of the SGSA implies a term that services will be provided with reasonable skill and care.

UCTA permits the exclusion of these terms, subject to the reasonableness test (see Practice note, Limiting liability: statutory and common law controls on limitation clauses: UCTA: statutory implied terms as to quality in supply of goods and UCTA: statutory implied duty of skill and care in supply of services).

The supplier's argument for excluding these provisions and all other implied terms is that the description of the services and the deliverables sets out the full quality requirements to which it is committing. These express commitments should influence whether the exclusion of implied terms is reasonable.

Unless a party notifies the other party that it intends to make a claim within the notice period, the other party shall have no liability for that claim. The notice period shall start on the day on which the party wishing to make a claim became[, or ought reasonably to have become,] aware of its having grounds to make a claim and shall expire [NUMBER] months from that date. The notice must be in writing and must identify the grounds for the claim in reasonable detail.

head.headtext: No liability for claims not notified within a specified time (optional clause)

para.paratext: The parties may wish to consider agreeing time limits for notifying claims or beginning litigation (reducing the usual six-year statutory limitation period for contract claims). This type of clause is more likely to benefit the supplier, as claims are more likely to be made by the customer.

In a particularly supplier-friendly agreement, the supplier could rework this clause so that it is just the customer who is barred from bringing claims that are not notified within a specific period, although a mutual clause may be more likely to survive the UCTA reasonableness test.
For more information, see Standard clause, Limitation of liability: Drafting note: No liability for claims not notified within [NUMBER] months (optional clause).
This clause 9 provides two sets of termination rights:

Clause 9.1 provides mutual termination rights for material breach or insolvency-related events. A supplier's right to terminate for a customer's insolvency is severely restricted due to the effects of the Corporate Insolvency and Governance Act 2020 (CIGA 2020), which is discussed in Drafting note, Termination for customer's insolvency: effects of CIGA 2020. We have therefore included a clause allowing either party to terminate pre-insolvency where the other party's financial position deteriorates.
Clause 9.2 is a one-way termination clause where the supplier can terminate for the customer's failure to make payments within a certain period or for repeated late payment.

This agreement does not include a right to terminate for the change of control of either party. This is on the assumption that it is the customer who is generally more likely to want to use that termination right. If the supplier does want to include a right to terminate on a change of control, see Standard clause, Termination: 1.1(q) for drafting.
For information on termination issues and longer form drafting options, see the following standard clauses and their drafting notes:
Termination.
Without affecting any other right or remedy available to it, either party to the Contract may terminate it with immediate effect by notifying the other party if:
the other party commits a material breach of any term of the Contract which :
is not capable of remedy; or
if capable of remedy, is not remedied within a period of [NUMBER] days by the other party after being notified to do so;

For drafting to specify that a breach of certain clauses constitutes a material breach, see Standard clause, Termination: clause 1.2. This drafting is more likely to favour the customer and therefore we have not included it in this agreement.

the other party takes or has taken against it (other than in relation to a solvent restructuring) any step or action towards its entering bankruptcy, administration, provisional liquidation or any composition or arrangement with its creditors, applying to court for or obtaining a moratorium under Part A1 of the Insolvency Act 1986, being wound up (whether voluntarily or by order of the court), being struck off the register of companies, having a receiver appointed to any of its assets or its entering a procedure in any jurisdiction with a similar effect to a procedure listed in this clause 9.1(b)];

head.headtext: Termination for customer's insolvency: effects of CIGA 2020

para.paratext: From 26 June 2020, CIGA 2020 introduced a new section 233B to the Insolvency Act 1986 (IA 1986). Broadly, this section makes it difficult or impossible for a supplier to terminate many contracts for the supply of goods or (non-financial) services on the grounds that the customer has entered a formal corporate insolvency procedure. At this point:
Termination rights arising before the start of the insolvency period cannot be exercised (section 233B(4)).
A termination provision triggered by entry into the insolvency process has no effect (section 233B(3)).
To terminate the contract unilaterally, a supplier needs one of the following:
A new termination right, arising after the start of the insolvency process and not triggered by the process.
Consent from the officer appointed to run the company or the insolvency process, such as an administrator.
Court permission, granted due to the financial hardship caused to the supplier.
It is still common to include termination for insolvency clauses in services agreements, partly because customers expect them and are not prevented by CIGA 2020 from using them.

A supplier affected by these rules should consider including a clause that would allow it to terminate at an early stage in a customer's financial problems (that is, before the customer enters insolvency), see clause 9.1(d).

For a detailed discussion about the effects of CIGA 2020 on termination of contracts, see Practice note, Restrictions on terminating supply contracts in insolvency proceedings: Section 233B: no termination of supplies of goods and services generally and in particular the section entitled Options for a supplier.

head.headtext: Shorter form termination for insolvency clause

para.paratext: In clause 9.1(b), "any step towards a specified insolvency process triggers termination. In a longer form agreement, the parties sometimes specify each step that triggers the termination right to ensure that the right arises at the earliest possible point. Assuming a low commercial risk of insolvency is envisaged, adopting a slightly more ambiguous form of words may be an acceptable trade-off for a more easily digestible contract.
the other party suspends or ceases, or threatens to suspend or cease, carrying on all or a substantial part of its business; or
the other party's financial position deteriorates so far as to reasonably justify the opinion that its ability to give effect to the terms of the Contract is in jeopardy.

This clause allows either party to terminate at an early stage in a party's financial problems, before any steps towards an insolvency process or even before any default in performing the contract has occurred. This could be particularly attractive for suppliers, who have very limited abilities to terminate a supply contract when the customer has entered insolvency (see Drafting note, Termination for customer's insolvency: effects of CIGA 2020). For more information about this clause, see Standard clause, Termination: Drafting note: Financial difficulties.
Without affecting any other right or remedy available to it, the Supplier may terminate the Contract with immediate effect by notifying the Customer if the Customer fails to pay:
any amount due under the Contract on the due date for payment and remains in default not less than [NUMBER] days after being notified to make that payment; or
any amounts due under the Contract by the due date for payment on [NUMBER] or more occasions in any [NUMBER]-month period.
This clause 9.2 gives the supplier the right to terminate if the customer is:
Late making a payment and fails to fix the issue within a further cure period.
Repeatedly late with making payments, regardless of whether it cures the issue or not.

The customer may argue that the supplier has a right to terminate for material breach and therefore this termination right is not necessary. The supplier usually wants a less ambiguous right to terminate for late payment rather than trying to prove that late payment amounts to a material or repudiatory breach. For more information, see Practice note, Contracts: termination: Termination for non-payment.
If a customer agrees to a right to terminate for late payment, it may want to:
Include an opportunity for the customer to fix the late payments before the termination right applies. We have included this in clause 9.2(a).
State that the right only applies if invoices over a certain amount are overdue.
Make the right mutual. This way, if the supplier owes money to the customer (for example, liquidated damages for delay), the customer can terminate if the supplier is late paying.

On termination of the Contract for whatever reason, the Customer shall immediately pay to the Supplier all of the Supplier's outstanding unpaid invoices and interest and, where no invoice has been submitted for Services supplied, the Supplier may submit an invoice, which shall be payable [immediately on receipt OR in accordance with clause 7.6].
Depending on the services, the customer may require:
Materials returning to the customer. For this drafting, see Standard document, Services agreement (pro-supplier): clause 18.1(b).

Assistance to help the customer transition the services either to a replacement supplier or itself. We have not included transitional assistance in this pro-supplier agreement. For a sample clause, see Standard document, Services agreement (pro-customer): clause 20.2.
Any provision of the Contract that expressly or by implication is intended to come into or continue in force on or after termination of the Contract shall remain in full force and effect.

Termination of the Contract shall not affect any of the rights, remedies, obligations or liabilities of the parties that have accrued up to the date of termination, including the right to claim damages in respect of any breach of the Contract which existed at or before the date of termination.
This clause sets out essential boilerplate provisions. For additional boilerplate clauses, see Standard document, Boilerplate agreement.

Force majeure. Neither party shall be liable for any delay or failure in performing any of its obligations for so long as and to the extent that the delay or failure results from events, circumstances or causes beyond its reasonable control.

Because the supplier is responsible for the bulk of the obligations under the contract, the customer may want to include a provision allowing it to terminate the contract if a force majeure event continues for more than a certain length of time. We have omitted this provision from this agreement because it is pro-supplier.
This short form force majeure clause also does not specify specific events that may amount to force majeure.

For more information on force majeure clauses, and a longer form clause that includes a detailed list of force majeure events and a termination provision, see Standard clause, Force majeure and its drafting notes.
Assignment and other dealings.

[Subject to clause 10.2(b) and clause 10.2(c), neither party shall OR The Customer shall not] assign, novate, transfer, mortgage, charge, subcontract, delegate, declare a trust over or deal in any other manner with any or all of its rights and obligations under the Contract without the prior written consent of the [other party OR Supplier] [(consent not to be unreasonably withheld or delayed)].
Either party may, after giving prior notice to the other party, assign, novate or transfer any of its rights and obligations under the Contract to:
an Affiliate of that party from time to time; or
any person to which it transfers [its business OR that part of its business to which the Contract relates].
[The Supplier may subcontract or delegate any or all of its obligations under the Contract to any third party[, provided that it:
notifies the Customer in advance of the subcontracting or delegation;
only subcontracts or delegates obligations to reputable third parties; and
remains responsible for the performance of the Contract and liable for all acts and omissions of third parties to which it subcontracts or delegates obligations as if they were its own].

The Supplier may at any time assign, novate, transfer, mortgage, charge, subcontract, delegate, declare a trust over or deal in any other manner with any or all of its rights and obligations under the Contract[, provided that it gives prior written notice to the Customer].
This clause 10.2 contains two options for assignment and other dealings:
Option 1. Each party needs the other party's consent to assign and deal with this agreement, subject to exceptions. If choosing this option:
use the first set of optional wording in each place in clause 10.2(a) and delete the second set;
consider using the optional exception in clause 10.2(b) for assignment and other dealings with affiliates and in connection with a business sale; and

use the first option in clause 10.2(c) so that the supplier can subcontract provided it uses reputable subcontractors and remains liable for their performance. Delete the second option in clause 10.2(c).
Option 2. The customer cannot assign or deal with this agreement without the supplier's consent. The supplier is expressly permitted to assign or deal with this agreement. If choosing this option:
use the second set of optional wording in each place in clause 10.2(a) and delete the first set; and
delete clause 10.2(b) and the first option in clause 10.2(c). Use the second option in clause 10.2(c).
Option 1 is relatively balanced. Choosing option 1 is likely to be easier to negotiate than option 2 which is more one-sided in the supplier's favour.

It is in the interests of the supplier as well as the customer to include a sufficiently detailed and well drafted service description. This will reduce the risk of disputes over what is and is not included in the services. Tips for drafting a service description for the supplier include:

Consider the services to be provided in detail from end to end, step by step. Also consider how the supplier should respond to unusual events which occur periodically (for example, in the context of delivery services, the provision by the customer of an incorrect address).

The supplier's own description of its services, as used in its marketing, may be a good starting point but usually requires some editing to make it clearer and more precise. The supplier should check to ensure that the description of its services does not over-promise and that any deadlines are realistic. The service description should be focused on what the supplier will actually do on a day-to-day basis, rather than the benefits that this will have for the customer (such as anticipated savings).
Obtain input from the individuals involved in the operational aspects of the services so that the drafting reflects the realities of the provision of the services.

Consider the division of responsibilities between the supplier and the customer. Be clear on any areas where the supplier's performance is dependent on something the customer must do first. Specific customer duties should be included where possible so that the supplier can invoke clause 4.2 if its performance is delayed by the customer's acts or omissions. For a discussion of how to deal with the customer's responsibilities, see Drafting note, Customer's obligations.

Avoid subjective descriptions such as "good" or "satisfactorily" where possible as these may result in disputes as to whether the standard has been met. Instead define the standards by measurable criteria. If it has been agreed that something will be done to the customer's satisfaction, make sure the customer is required to act reasonably.

Avoid leaving matters to be agreed by both parties as this will cause problems if the parties cannot subsequently agree. If something cannot be agreed upfront, try to include a mechanism for working out the relevant issue.

After contract signature, additional services or variations to existing services agreed by the parties should be documented in writing to avoid any future dispute. In this short form agreement, clause 10.5 provides that any variations to any part of the agreement must be in writing and signed by both parties. When considering changes to the services, suppliers should consider whether the price needs revising as well. For a formal change control mechanism for agreeing and pricing changes to the services, see Standard document, Services agreement (pro-supplier): clause 9.
